text.p: Swedish Labor Minister Ulrica Messing criticized Trelleborg AB on Wednesday over the handling of a year-old U.S. strike by one of its companies.

"I was both disturbed and surprised about how a company can have one moral code in Sweden, but have another abroad," she said in a speech in Stockholm. Her remarks were translated into English and released by the Swedish embassy here.
Some 200 workers represented by four unions have been on strike at the company's BIT Manufacturing Co., a sulfuric acid facility in Copperhill, Tennessee, since April 30, 1996.
Trelleborg said Monday that it agreed to sell the facility to investors, including managers of its Boliden Intertrade subsidiary in Atlanta, which owns BIT Manufacturing.

But Messing said the company should resolve the dispute before proceeding with the sale, adding that she has received reports that its has employed strike breakers and armed guards, and refused to negotiate with or recognize the unions.

"This sounds like gangster methods brought back from the 1930s. But this has happened now, in 1997, in a Swedish-owned company, " she said. "This damages not only Trelleborg's image, but also that of other Swedish companies with overseas operations."
